posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
As we have after the last couple of years ( 2023 thread , 2022 thread ), the WPILib team is seeking feedback on the many improvements and changes made to WPILib in 2024. This can be about the library itself, tools, or documentation.

I like to structure this kind of feedback ask as looking for the good, the bad, and the ugly:

The good (this was awesome, please keep doing it) : What worked well? What did you find particularly beneficial to your team? What would you like to see more of?

The bad (don’t repeat this, please figure out how to improve it ): What didn’t work? What did you struggle with? What would you like to see changed?

The ugly (worse than bad, please aim to never let this happen again) : What did you have to hack around to make it work for you? What made figuring out the right solution more difficult for you (e.g. wasted precious time)?

( Other feedback structures such as Start/Stop/Continue or Thorns/Roses/Buds are also welcome–whatever works for you!)

We’re currently working on our plans/priorities for next year (we’re also working to finalize updates to our longer-term roadmap to share with the community). Suggestions are certainly welcome, but I’ll note that since WPILib is an all-volunteer effort / community project, the best way to see a feature get implemented is to implement it yourself, or get someone in the community interested in implementing it. We welcome both ideas and contributors!

posts.name: Josh P
posts.cooked:
My perspective is that of someone who was slightly removed from FRC software for the last season or two before this one.

I haven’t thought very hard about bads or uglies yet, but I want to point at one extreme good - docs.wpilib.org . Any time I or one of my students had a question where my first reaction was “well surely someone has written the answer for this down somewhere”, I would go there before doing a CD search, because we had about a 75%-80% chance of finding the answer on our first search. Keep up the good work and the great documentation is really appreciated!

link_counts.title: FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked:
Documentation, FRC docs are a lifesaver and the API docs are super convenient.

Support, the ability to ask a question and get a clear concise answer quickly is genuinely incredible. Huge thanks to all the WPILib maintainers lurking in the FRC discord answering questions tirelessly.

AdvantageScope being shipped with WPILib. I cannot say enough good things about AdvantageScope it has made the way I debug code so much nicer compared to Shuffleboard in 2023.

The beta release system was really nice, being able to see the differences in how WPILib would work for the coming year early without having to link to local development builds.

Not having a good driver dashboard shipped with WPILib is a bit annoying. Shuffleboard is pretty dead if something like Elastic (incredible, thank you so much to the developer it was a great experience this year) being shipped with WPILib could be nice.

Documentation for GradleRIO feels lacking for more advanced tasks with things like the vendordep json file specification being… undocumented? Along with this there are a few things which just have really painful error messages to understand if you don’t know whats happened eg. GradleRIO#710 or GradleRIO#727 . Again the support around this was really good seeing some of these issues before encountering them was really good allowing me to help people out when they encounter them later.

Huge thanks to the WPILib team and maintainers of community projects for the incredible experience programming for FRC this year!

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: @Gold87 did a fab job with Elastic, and his accessibility on here and Discord made it a pleasure to work with him on fixes and improvements.  I second not having a good dashboard ship with WPILib is annoying, but I found Elastic to be fabulous to work on.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: It would’ve been nice if it was easily documented how to add a grade task to clear the deploy folder on deploy (or have it baked into the deploy process by default). SSHing in was fine, but it was confusing because /home/lvuser/deploy was actually owned by admin , so you couldn’t ssh as lvuser to delete files. Unconfirmed if having stale files in the deploy folder caused any issues, but it would be nice to always have a ‘clean’ deploy folder

Good:

The documentation greatly improved from last year. Wayyy easier for less experienced kids to learn.

Command-based continues to impress, especially with us standardizing on Command factories. However there should be more docs on applications of Triggers.

Ugly:

I understand why the deploy directory is kept each time, to preserve flash memory, but I’d love an optional add-on that clears stuff that exists on the RIO but not the code.

Bad:

Shuffleboard, still. It ate up computers’ entire CPU at one point in the season…

Honestly, it might be optimal if it used rsync or something similar to actually sync and not remove anything that doesn’t change to save on deploy time (though i’m not sure if its even a non-negligible amount for most people;s applications), though I guess that would imply having to distribute rsync on the programming laptop side too, and figuring out what invocation’s needed.

The only real conceivable issue I can think of with stale files is to do with PathPlanner’s AutoBuilder chooser, which iirc scans the deploy directory for autos to run. Renaming one might leave the old name behind, or show deleted autos, which probably is somewhat confusing to people that haven’t found the build.gradle lines to clear the build directory.

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
Rsync is difficult because we need to support windows, so we’d have to build our own algorithm.

Before this year, a built in way to clear the deploy folder had never been asked for, so we never thought to add it. Especially since we really don’t like deleting users files randomly.

We’ll add a flag for next year to clear the folder, but it will be disabled by default.

Also I had thought we have changed the deploy folder to lvuser and not admin. But I guess not. That’s something else to fix.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
crueter:

However there should be more docs on applications of Triggers.

This is planned for 2025.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ethan Scime
posts.cooked:
The Good: This was our first season really making use of WPILIB (we were previously LabVIEW), and overall we had great success with it all and the documentation was extremely helpful and clear. I can’t imagine our robot being even half as capable without WPILIB, so kudos to the whole team that works on it and thanks so much - you all do invaluable work. We were also impressed with how much was available to us as a RobotPy team, it was a rare moment when we encountered something we weren’t able to replicate from Java examples. Overall great experience, had very few issues or bugs even in the first year of RobotPy official support.

The tools that shipped with WPILIB this year were also extremely reliable and super useful. AdvantageScope being packaged with WPILIB was genuinely incredible and has started us on a path towards more effective failure analysis.

The new RobotPy installer was fantastic and simplified our deployment process significantly. I know this was a close-to-the-season-start kind of thing, but it was an extremely good change so I want to point it out in particular. It was much easier to get the new process across to students.

The Bad: We had some frustration with the changes to SysID this year. We relied on it in the offseason to tune our swerve drivetrain for the first time, and while we knew it would be changing for the season decently early, the changes weren’t available to us for use in time for us to actually USE SysID this year. There still isn’t a Python example available, and we’re still not entirely clear on how to integrate it into our code from the Java/C++ examples.

This is more than likely a structural issue, but we did have some amount of trouble with loop overruns this year. We were never overrunning by more than a couple of milliseconds even with our poor optimization, but of course that still issues the warning at a very high frequency, which made it super annoying to track any actual errors that may have come up in testing. Maybe this already exists and I couldn’t find it, but some way to suppress the warning like you can with “Joystick Unplugged” warnings would help us (I can certainly see the opposite argument where you want teams to pay very close attention when this particular warning arises and don’t want to encourage/allow suppressing the warning).

For quite some time our software was always failing tests whenever we had a SPARK MAX created anywhere in our code. We started just bypassing tests, which is bad for a number of reasons, and we never circled back to figuring out what was causing it. Feels worth mentioning, I think I heard some others had a similar problem.

The Ugly: When Shuffleboard works, it’s great. When it doesn’t work, it’s downright infuriating. We had a number of recurring issues with it freezing some or all of the displayed values, not updating properly, or locking buttons and not unlocking them. Occasionally we had issues where it wouldn’t display properly on any monitor, always defaulting to a scale that was too large for our screens no matter what we did to it. Reboots of the operator console computer seemed to fix it just fine, it was just weird and annoying.

I couldn’t decide whether to put this in “Ugly” or “Bad” so it’s going at the bottom as uncategorized. I don’t know if this is really an issue so much as something I’d like to mention was happening to us, but AdvantageScope seems to hang for a very long time before opening. We didn’t have this issue before using it through the WPILIB install, but now it takes a good 30+ seconds to open. This may well be the computers we’re using it on, but I just don’t see this kind of startup latency with any of the other WPILIB tools or frankly any other software on my personal laptop.

Again, thanks for all you do! WPILIB was an outstanding tool for us this season, and I just want to reiterate how great it’s been!

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
MrMARVINMan:

recurring issues with it freezing some or all of the displayed values, not updating properly, or locking buttons and not unlocking them.

Yeah we continuously had issues where a boolean switch would be untoggleable. Possible something to do with persistence, though unsure.  Usually happened after a code deploy, and only fix was to restart shuffleboard

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
MrMARVINMan:

There still isn’t a Python example available, and we’re still not entirely clear on how to integrate it into our code from the Java/C++ examples.

See examples/SysId at main · robotpy/examples · GitHub

MrMARVINMan:

This is more than likely a structural issue, but we did have some amount of trouble with loop overruns this year.

If the problem you’re having isn’t solved by using the batch signal API for CTRE motors, then it’s possible that it’s not your code – nobody has taken a hard look at performance for Python, and my team has never had a particularly complex robot (and we don’t use command based) so it’s challenging for me to do so as we never run into loop overruns. It is likely there is some low hanging fruit that could help with this if it were identified.

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
MrMARVINMan:

AdvantageScope seems to hang for a very long time before opening

This was an issue in some of the earlier WPILib releases due to AdvantageScope being packaged in a new format for WPILib distribution on Windows. It should have been fixed in AdvantageScope 3.1.0/WPILib 2024.3.1 (note that you would need to run the WPILib installer to get the update rather than just changing the project version).

link_counts.title: Add link to Python SysId example by calcmogul · Pull Request #2636 · wpilibsuite/frc-docs · GitHub

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
The Good

The zero-to-robot section is incredibly helpful for new teams and a resource I can point them to and know they will have a working robot afterward.

The zero-to-robot section is incredibly helpful for new teams and a resource I can point them to and know they will have a working robot afterward.

The command-based documentation has a wide variety of examples and helpful hints for getting used to a new paradigm.

The command-based documentation has a wide variety of examples and helpful hints for getting used to a new paradigm.

Most of the example projects thoroughly explain how to handle the demonstrated concept with code that is easy to follow.

Most of the example projects thoroughly explain how to handle the demonstrated concept with code that is easy to follow.

The Bad

The networking section is incredibly important and yet it’s hidden near the end of the documentation near things that most teams will skip over, such as XRP and contributing. IMO this section should be right after zero to robot, as it covers the most common issues you will run into right after getting everything running.

The networking section is incredibly important and yet it’s hidden near the end of the documentation near things that most teams will skip over, such as XRP and contributing. IMO this section should be right after zero to robot, as it covers the most common issues you will run into right after getting everything running.

In a similar vein, the intro to PID is under Advanced Programming and then under Advanced Controls. So PID is only for the doubly advanced programming student? On the other hand, a huge portion of the documentation considers PID to be something that is already understood.

In a similar vein, the intro to PID is under Advanced Programming and then under Advanced Controls. So PID is only for the doubly advanced programming student? On the other hand, a huge portion of the documentation considers PID to be something that is already understood.

I would like the documentation to be re-ordered so a student can work through it progressively. In particular, I think a good portion of this “advanced controls” section could be moved to an intro to controls section so that new teams can get all the basics of controls.

I would like the documentation to be re-ordered so a student can work through it progressively. In particular, I think a good portion of this “advanced controls” section could be moved to an intro to controls section so that new teams can get all the basics of controls.

The Ugly

Right after the game launch, the wpilib section on where to download all the software was a screenshot of the documentation?!? None of the links were clickable for several days. I ended up having to google each component and find the downloads through each supplier. At some point this was fixed. It was something of a humorous mistake as it looked like there was text but it was just an image of text.
